reasoning:

**Analysis:**

I can form several two pairs from my current cards. Testing the 7s and 6s combination: the base two pair gives 20 chips, and with the 7 of Hearts retriggered by Hanging Chad, that's 7 × 3 = 21 chips, plus the remaining cards (7 + 6 + 6 = 19), totaling 60 chips before multipliers.

With a base multiplier of 2 and Abstract Joker adding 18, I get a 20x multiplier, resulting in 1,200 chips—still far short of the 2,750 average I need per hand. I'm facing a critical constraint: only one discard remains, which means I can swap up to 5 cards and then have exactly 4 hands left to play. The deck still holds useful cards like three 6s, one 7, three 2s, and two 9s, but my limited discards make it risky to pursue a different strategy now. a 2, so roughly 18% chance of hitting Three of a Kind this way.

But I could also discard all cards except the pair of 6s and draw 5 new cards instead. With 3 sixes remaining in the deck, drawing 5 cards gives me about a 38% probability of completing the set—significantly better odds than the single draw approach.

The 2 of Clubs is a Gold Card worth $3, but it doesn't contribute to forming Three of a Kind, so I should discard it along with the other non-pair cards. I'll keep just the 6s and draw 5 fresh cards to maximize my chances of improvement.
